Q: What is the core Stoic idea Marcus repeats throughout Meditations?
ExpA: Control what you can control accept what you cannot
A:
Core Stoic idea Marcus repeats: that the highest good is to “live according to nature” — to work consciously with God/Providence for the common good; virtue alone enables this, the wise man is self‑sufficient and externals are indifferent, and one must control the will and bring desires under the ruling principle.

Sources: 1393 (Meditations); 46 (Meditations); 55 (Meditations); 58 (Meditations).
Contexts:
Stoics, a philosophic system founded by Zeno (4th century B.C.), and
systematised by Chrysippus (3rd century B.C.). Their physical theory
was a pantheistic materialism, their summum bonum "to live according
to nature." Their wise man needs nothing, he is sufficient to himself;
virtue is good, vice bad, external things indifferent.

they live their lives as fellow-workers with God.

Such is the system which underlies the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius.
Some knowledge of it is necessary to the right understanding of the
book, but for us the chief interest lies elsewhere. We do not come to
Marcus Aurelius for a treatise on Stoicism. He is no head of a school to

but for the good of the whole. The highest good of man is consciously
to work with God for the common good, and this is the sense in which
the Stoic tried to live in accord with nature. In the individual it
is virtue alone which enables him to do this; as Providence rules the
universe, so virtue in the soul must rule man.

In Logic, the Stoic system is noteworthy for their theory as to the

the power of the will; whereas health, wealth, honour, and other such
are generally not so. The Stoic was called upon to control his desires
and affections, and to guide his opinion; to bring his whole being
under the sway of the will or leading principle, just as the universe
is guided and governed by divine Providence. This is a special

Metrics.R: The score is 0.68 because the retrieval includes direct statements of Marcus's recurring Stoic theme—e.g. 'Their summum bonum "to live according to nature."', 'The highest good of man is consciously to work with God for the common good.' and 'they live their lives as fellow-workers with God.'—but it is diluted by irrelevant material about origins and technical metaphysics (e.g. 'founded by Zeno (4th century B.C.)...', 'pantheistic materialism', 'for us the chief interest lies elsewhere.'), making it partially but not fully focused on the core idea.

The score is 0.81 because most top-ranked nodes in the retrieval contexts support the Stoic core: node 1 states the Stoic goal as 'to live according to nature' and that 'external things [are] indifferent,' and nodes 3 and 4 (ranks 3 and 4) reinforce this with 'virtue in the soul must rule man' / 'Providence rules the universe' and 'The Stoic was called upon to control his desires and affections' — all aligning with 'control what you can, accept what you cannot.' It is not higher because node 2 in the retrieval contexts (rank 2) only notes 'Such is the system which underlies the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius,' and 'it does not mention controlling what you can or accepting what you cannot and so does not directly support the expected answer,' so this less relevant node appears above other supportive material and reduces precision.

Q: How does Marcus describe the proper response to insults?
ExpA: They harm the insulter not you remain rational
A: Marcus says one should not abandon one’s philosophy or heed silly people when insulted; instead show forbearance and not lose your temper. Treat petty insults with magnanimity — ask why a small thing should make you sorry, and if you cannot take it joyously, at least suffer patiently. Be kind even to those who hate you, and correct their error ingenuously and meekly rather than by ostentation.

Q: What does Marcus emphasize as the 'guiding principle' for decision-making?

Q: According to Marcus; why should one avoid seeking praise?
ExpA: Because praise is fleeting and given by those who may not understand virtue
A:
Marcus advises avoiding the pursuit of praise because: (1) a rightly understanding person does good without seeking applause and will continue to do good for its own sake (chunk 414); (2) one should intend only that actions be good and beneficial to the public, since praise is fleeting and those once commended are soon forgotten (chunk 621); (3) life is short and both praiser and praised will soon be dust, and praise is limited and local (chunk 760); (4) praise from people who cannot even approve themselves is not worth regard (chunk 252).

Sources: 414 (Meditations), 621 (Meditations), 760 (Meditations), 252 (Meditations)

Q: What effect does reading the play have on its readers?
A: Reading the play exerts a compulsive, riveting effect: readers may try to stop or destroy the book yet find themselves irresistibly drawn back, feeling terror or an intense, poignant joy. Q: Why is the story 'The Repairer of Reputations' considered unreliable narration?
ExpA: The narrator Hildred is delusional and invents conspiracies
A: Because the tale is presented through a single, subjective perspective that relays Mr. Wilde’s insistent, self‑justifying claims rather than an external, corroborating account. The narrator speaks in first person (“I saw... I knocked...”), and Mr. Wilde himself insists on proving his correctness about being a “Repairer of Reputations” (“I only wanted to demonstrate that I was correct. You said it was impossible...”), which invites doubt. As other excerpts note, a sequence “as narrated by [one person]” can look different when seen by others, so the story’s lone viewpoint makes its account unreliable.

Q: What was the primary purpose of the Federalist Papers?
ExpA: To advocate for ratification of the U.S. Constitution

The primary purpose was to persuade the people (especially of New York) to support the new Constitution by explaining and defending it in a clear and convincing light.

Q: Why does Publius argue for a large republic?
ExpA: It better controls factions through diversity of interests
A: Publius (Madison) argues that a large republic is preferable because it (1) provides a bigger pool of fit candidates for representatives and thus better guards against the influence of small cabals, since representatives must be limited in number and in a small republic are proportionally fewer choices; and (2) a republic (unlike a direct democracy) can be extended over a large region, allowing those benefits to operate on a greater scale.
Contexts:
and then betray the interests, of the people. The question resulting is,
whether small or extensive republics are more favorable to the election
of proper guardians of the public weal; and it is clearly decided in
favor of the latter by two obvious considerations:

In the first place, it is to be remarked that, however small the

In the first place, it is to be remarked that, however small the
republic may be, the representatives must be raised to a certain number,
in order to guard against the cabals of a few; and that, however large
it may be, they must be limited to a certain number, in order to
guard against the confusion of a multitude. Hence, the number of

guard against the confusion of a multitude. Hence, the number of
representatives in the two cases not being in proportion to that of
the two constituents, and being proportionally greater in the small
republic, it follows that, if the proportion of fit characters be not
less in the large than in the small republic, the former will present a

the nature of the latter. The true distinction between these forms was
also adverted to on a former occasion. It is, that in a democracy, the
people meet and exercise the government in person; in a republic,
they assemble and administer it by their representatives and agents. A
democracy, consequently, will be confined to a small spot. A republic
may be extended over a large region.
